The D.C. Council is pushing back the opening of the National Geographic Society’s new Washington, DC, museum, which was set to open this spring, by a year. The May 4 move followed a meeting of the council’s planning and preservation committees, which recommended that the National Geographic Society delay the opening of its new building in the District in order to allow the institution to conduct a construction review and adjust to the possibility of a campus in the city.“We will do that as soon as we can,” council chair Tom Gilliam, a Washington Republican, said in a statement. “The science and history of our planet is at stake, and we will not let it slide. We are rethinking the future of our city, Washington, and our region, and how we build for the future.”
